Pay Your Invoice or Retainer Online

As a courtesy to our clients, Spectrum Legal Group, LLP accepts credit cards for payments of invoices and retainers. As an added service, Spectrum Legal Group, LLP has partnered with LawPay to provide the convenience of making online payments via a secure webpage. Paying online eliminates the need for writing a check, and saves time and postage.

This service may be used to pay invoices or retainers in the following manner:

Existing clients wishing to pay an invoice they have received will need to enter the Account Number and Statement Number as it appears on the invoice, along with the amount being paid. If the firm is unable to match your payment to an existing account, your charge may be rejected. To pay an invoice, click on the link below.

New clients may also make a retainer payment online. The submission of a retainer payment does not create an attorney-client relationship. An attorney-client relationship is only created upon the agreement as to terms which are provided in writing, signed by an authorized attorney of Spectrum Legal Group, LLP. Upon direction of a Spectrum Legal Group, LLP attorney and receipt/execution of a retainer letter, new clients may make their retainer payment by clicking the “Retainer Payment” link below.

Existing clients may also replenish their retainer as directed by their attorney. To replenish a retainer, click on the link below.

Credit card payment notice: Due to bank processing times, it may take 2-3 days before your account reflects your payment.

Disclaimer

This web site provides general information on the skills, services, and experience of individual attorneys at Spectrum Legal Group, LLP. This information does not constitute legal advice or a substitute for legal counsel. This publicly available information does not give rise to a lawyer-client relationship between you and our firm. The use of the email contact tool does not suggest or constitute any attorney-client relationship between us.

The Wyoming Rule of Professional Conduct for Attorneys require the following disclaimer: The Wyoming State Bar does not certify any lawyers as a specialist or expert.

Anyone considering a lawyer should conduct independent investigation of the lawyer’s credentials and ability and not rely upon advertisements or self-proclaimed expertise.
